body: How about you do `typeorm migration:generate -n FoundChanges`

@gintsgints that seems will generate the migration file in `ts`. In RDBMS (production), I will prefer not to give app permission to Create or drop table / indexes. Therefore generate it into `.sql` is preferred.

Besides, using the native syntax of query runner is not as good when we want to switch between mysql/postgres/mssql/nosql.

Imagination on how the dry run syntax can work:
1. there is two migration file named `initial.ts` and `second.ts`
2. run `typeorm migration:dry-run --driver=postgres` or  `typeorm migration:dry-run --env=production`
3. generate file `postgres/up/initial.sql` and `postgres/up/second.sql` (throw error if driver is not supported)
4. the sql file generated will update the migration table on success

I might be able to spend some time working on this feature if the changes to the code base is small,

issue.title: Schema migration generated .sql files

repository.name: typeorm
repository.description: ORM for TypeScript and JavaScript. Supports MySQL, PostgreSQL, MariaDB, SQLite, MS SQL Server, Oracle, SAP Hana, WebSQL databases. Works in NodeJS, Browser, Ionic, Cordova and Electron platforms.

issue.body:
**Issue type:**

[ ] question
[ ] bug report
[x ] feature request
[ ] documentation issue

**Database system/driver:**

[ ] `cordova`
[ ] `mongodb`
[x ] `mssql`
[x ] `mysql` / `mariadb`
[x ] `oracle`
[x ] `postgres`
[ ] `cockroachdb`
[x ] `sqlite`
[x ] `sqljs`
[ ] `react-native`
[ ] `expo`

**TypeORM version:**

[ x] `latest`
[ ] `@next`
[ ] `0.x.x` (or put your version here)

**Steps to reproduce or a small repository showing the problem:**

This is a duplicate of [this request](https://github.com/typeorm/typeorm/issues/3037) to add support for generation of .sql files for output of a migration.

Per the contribution guidelines, I'm submitting this request in hopes of implementing it and submitting a pull request.  

**Additional CLI config**
e.g.
```
"cli":{
    "scriptsDir": "/scripts/generated"
}
```

**Expected CLI behavior**
Adds a -s (--script) flag for signaling script output and -n (--name) for specifying the file name.

e.g.
```typeorm migration:run -s -n file_name.sql ```
```typeorm migration:run -s [matches migration name].sql```

**Expected output**
SQL in the dialect of the target server in a runnable script file

e.g.
```
START TRANSACTION
CREATE TABLE "SomeTableName" ("id" SERIAL NOT NULL, "createDate" TIMESTAMP NOT NULL DEFAULT now(), "updateDate" TIMESTAMP NOT NULL DEFAULT now(), "version" integer NOT NULL, "name" character varying(100) NOT NULL, CONSTRAINT "PK_fdb7139df4ab7684559efc8651b" PRIMARY KEY ("id"))

INSERT INTO "_migrations"("timestamp", "name") VALUES ($1, $2)
COMMIT
```

issue.title: Command line option for migration:generate to output code in console

repository.name: typeorm
repository.description: ORM for TypeScript and JavaScript. Supports MySQL, PostgreSQL, MariaDB, SQLite, MS SQL Server, Oracle, SAP Hana, WebSQL databases. Works in NodeJS, Browser, Ionic, Cordova and Electron platforms.

issue.body:
**Issue type:**

[x] feature request

**TypeORM version:**

[x] `latest`

I often find it useful to check my changes to schema with migration generation system, so I find myself generating migration named "Test" and then deleting it right after. It would be very useful to just print out generated code to stdout.

issue.title: Dry run or pretend run of migrations?

repository.name: typeorm
repository.description: ORM for TypeScript and JavaScript. Supports MySQL, PostgreSQL, MariaDB, SQLite, MS SQL Server, Oracle, SAP Hana, WebSQL databases. Works in NodeJS, Browser, Ionic, Cordova and Electron platforms.

issue.body:
**Issue type:**

[X] question
[ ] bug report
[ ] feature request
[ ] documentation issue

Is there any way to try running the migrations to see if there are any errors, and always roll back?  This would be nice for apps where we just want to see if there would be migration errors first (with this dry-run), before stopping the app servers and running the migrations for real.

issue.title: Exit with code 1 if no changes were found

repository.name: typeorm
repository.description: ORM for TypeScript and JavaScript. Supports MySQL, PostgreSQL, MariaDB, SQLite, MS SQL Server, Oracle, SAP Hana, WebSQL databases. Works in NodeJS, Browser, Ionic, Cordova and Electron platforms.

issue.body:
### Description of change

This makes `migration:generate` exit with error code 1 if no changes were found. In general I think this qualifies as a non-successful run, but the main benefit is that it allows the command to be used to verify that there are no changes between the code and the current database schema.

I am not sure how best to make a test case for this. Any pointers on this would be appreciated.

Fixes #3037

body: We need to add dry run

issue.title: feat: Add check and dryrun to migration generate

repository.name: typeorm
repository.description: ORM for TypeScript and JavaScript. Supports MySQL, PostgreSQL, MariaDB, SQLite, MS SQL Server, Oracle, SAP Hana, WebSQL databases. Works in NodeJS, Browser, Ionic, Cordova and Electron platforms.

issue.body:
### Description of change

There was some disagreement with a previous change I suggested in https://github.com/typeorm/typeorm/pull/6978. The proposal to (also) add a "check" mode makes sense, so I have added that here, but kept backwards compatibility when the new flag is not used.

In addition there was a feeling that the original issue, https://github.com/typeorm/typeorm/issues/3037, was not resolved, and rightly so. So I have also added a "dryrun" mode that will print out the migration instead of writing it to a file.

Hopefully fixes #3037 

### Pull-Request Checklist

- [X] Code is up-to-date with the `master` branch
- [X] `npm run lint` passes with this change
- [ ] `npm run test` passes with this change
- [X] This pull request links relevant issues as `Fixes #0000`
- [ ] There are new or updated unit tests validating the change - N/A
- [ ] Documentation has been updated to reflect this change - N/A
- [X] The new commits follow conventions explained in [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/typeorm/typeorm/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
